thread.title: S. Dakota beats Missouri St. 40-10 with 529 yards of offense
thread.title_full: S. Dakota beats Missouri St. 40-10 with 529 yards of offense

title: S. Dakota beats Missouri St. 40-10 with 529 yards of offense
text:
Bergner hits 5 field goals, including 53-yarder, as South Dakota rolls past Missouri St. 40-10 THE ASSOCIATED PRESS   7:06   7:06   
Subjects: 
Missouri (724) 

VERMILLION, South Dakota â€” South Dakota shook off the euphoria of beating North Dakota State last week and downed Missouri State 40-10 in the Missouri Valley Conference on Saturday. 
After 14 straight conference losses, the Coyotes have won two in a row behind strong defensive efforts. 
"Our defense was swarming all day long. It starts with great defense," South Dakota coach Joe Glenn said. 
The Coyotes held the Bears to just 155 total yards, while rolling up 529. 
"We're pretty happy with the way the guys played up front," Glenn said. "You've got to feel good about putting 529 yards on somebody." 
Kicker Miles Bergner, whose last-second field goal lifted the Coyotes to a stunning win over North Dakota State last weekend, kicked three field goals in the first quarter to give USD a 9-0 lead. He added one more in the second half to tie the school record of four in a game. 
"Happy day for Miles Bergner. He did a good job for us," Glenn said. 
The Coyotes (4-2, 2-2 Missouri Valley) took the opening kickoff and moved into field goal range where Bergner kicked a career-long 53-yarder for a 3-0 Coyotes lead. He later kicked field goals of 29, 28 and 36 yards. 
Missouri State (1-6, 0-4) erased most of the early lead when Deion Holliman returned a kickoff 100 yards to make it 9-7 with 1:40 left in the first quarter. 
The Bears' only other threat ended at the USD 4, following a 60-yard run by Jason Randall. Marcelo Bonani kicked a 21-yard field goal. 
Randall ran 10 times for 77 yards. 
Defensively, USD held Missouri State to just 49 yards in the first half. The Bears' longest drive in the first two quarters was 13 yards. 
Michael Fredrick and Nate Gunn filled in for injured starter Trevor Bouma. Fredrick ran for 129 yards and a score and Gunn added 46 yards and a TD. 
Ryan Saeger completed 20 of 29 passes for 275 yards, including a 34-yard TD to Eric Shufford. 
Brandt Van Roekel caught seven passes for 86 yards. 
The Coyotes took control in a 17-point third quarter. 
"We've got some wind in our sails and bounce in our step," Glenn said. "I knew we could play better."
